column2: In 1820, in the small Sicilian town of Giarre, generations of the Casella Family worked passionately growing grapes. Decades later, Filippo Casella migrated to Australia with the hope of continuing their family’s wine tradition. Searching for the best grapes for his wine, he selected specific parcels of fruit from a variety of regions in South Australia. His aim? To showcase the best of Australian Shiraz. Expect concentrated notes of ripe blackcurrant and cherry, with black pepper and chocolate. It’s ideal with grilled meats, fresh off the barbecue.
column9: Black Pepper, Black Plum, Spice, Vanilla

column2: Coonawarra's cool climate and famous terra rossa soils are now rightfully celebrated the world over. This region's reds are seen amongst Australia's greatest. Much of this is down to Samuel Wynn and his son, David, who bought an almost desolate vineyard in 1951 with no expectations of making a profit. Today, the Wynns Coonawarra Estate label is one of the most recognisable in Australia. This Shiraz has upheld the great reputation for more than half a century. Bright. Fresh. Silky. It's medium-bodied, with juicy notes of red fruits, blackberry and spicy black pepper. Try it with beef or veggie dumplings and a spiced yoghurt dressing.
column9: Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Cloves, Sweet Spice, Tobacco, Vanilla

column2: Smith & Wright is the creation of a duo with a passion for enjoyable, fruit-forward wine that's best enjoyed with company. Delve into intense notes of ripe raspberry, cherry, vanilla and pepper.
column9: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Raspberry, Red Cherry, Red Fruit

column2: Yellow Tail Pinot Grigio is zesty, bright and refreshingly light. With gentle notes of apple, pear, citrus and just a touch of passionfruit, it's a delicious fruit-forward foray into Pinot Grigio territory. Enjoy yours with colourful salads or simple fish dishes.
column9: Tropical Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Green Apple, Lime, Melon, Passionfruit, Peach

column2: Full-bodied and decadent with a lingering finish, Yellow Tail Malbec is bursting with blackberry and cherry notes. Soft swathes of dark chocolate, vanilla and spice emerge through the palate for a deliciously steak-loving sip.
column9: Jammy, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Chocolate

column2: In 1788, 'punishment by transportation' to Australia became the sentence of choice for convicts in the UK. If you were guilty of one of 19 crimes, then you were chosen to build a new life across the world. This wine shows that, sometimes, it pays to break to rules. It's a Shiraz-dominated blend made from grapes sourced across South Eastern Australia. Aged in American oak, it has full flavours of vanilla, chocolate and cedar spice. A great partner for braised beef.
column9: Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Vanilla

column2: Penfolds is an iconic name in Australian wine. Widely regarded as the country’s leading producer, their reputation for excellence is recognised throughout the world. Their tradition of crafting fortified wines dates back to 1844 – the winery’s founding year – and this elegant bottling is a tribute to their over 170 years of winemaking greatness. It’s a blend of outstanding wines that have each been matured separately in oak, then combined to create Penfolds’ distinctive Tawny house style. Discover opulent notes of toasted nuts, chocolate, raisin, fruitcake and clove, with a long, fresh finish. It’s ready to drink now, so enjoy it with a classic cheeseboard.
column9: Walnut, Caramel, Dried Fruit, Raisin

column2: Smith & Wright is the creation of a duo with a passion for enjoyable, fruit-forward wine that's best enjoyed with company. Expect juicy notes of peach and lemon blossom, a creamy slather of vanilla and a crisp, refreshing finish.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach

column2: Smith & Wright is the creation of a duo with a passion for enjoyable, fruit-forward wine that's best enjoyed with company. Pair this Merlot's fruity lashings of red fruit, vanilla and sweet spices with red meats and roasted vegetables.
column9: Vanilla, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£29.99 per bottle,75CL,Cabernet Sauvignon,,Screwcap,10.4,Black Plum
column9: Red

column1: Jam Shed Rosé 2020, South East Australia
column2: Jam Shed was created with one thing in mind – to create delicious, seriously drinkable wines. They’ve travelled the world to find the best spots for their grapes and bring you flavourful bottles at exceptional value. This rosé comes from sunny South East Australia, where the warm weather makes for fantastically ripe flavours. It’s juicy and medium-sweet with notes of strawberry, redcurrant and grapefruit. The perfect bottle to enjoy with rich cheeses.
column9: Cream, Red Cherry, Strawberry

column2: Expect a lush palate of peach and citrus delivered through a creamy mouthfeel that's polished with a dusting of vanilla and spice. It's the perfect partner for a comforting roast chicken dinner.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach

column2: In quintessential Aussie Shiraz style, Yellow Tail Shiraz is both rich and lively, with a deep red berry, spice and liquorice palate. Indulge in a generous glass with a chocolate dessert for a real treat.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Jammy

column2: In 1788, 'punishment by transportation' to Australia became the sentence of choice for convicts in the UK. 19 Crimes is made in tribute to those rogues who forged a new life across the world. And this Cabernet is every bit as bold as their stories. It's aged with 100% American oak, so expect flavours of redcurrants, dark cherries, vanilla and chocolate. Great with beef shortribs.
column9: Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Spice, Vanilla

column1: De Bortoli Botrytis Semillon 2019 Half Bottle, Riverina
column2: Inspired by the late Australian designer Florence Broadhurst, this is a limited release botrytis dessert wine from Semillon masters De Bortoli. Whilst made from the same grape as De Bortoli's iconic Noble One Semillon, one of the most awarded wines in history, this is a lighter, more refreshing style. Pair its citrus and spicy apricot notes and fresh acidity with fruit desserts.
column9: Orange Marmalade, Citrus Fruit, Honey, Honeysuckle

column2: Tyrrell's Vat 1 Sémillon was first produced in 1963, and is the most awarded and recognised Sémillon from the Hunter Valley. It's sourced from two of the best blocks of Sémillon which have vines dating back to 1923. This prime location combined with old vines produces a wine with juicy lime fruit alongside notes of honey, lanolin and a nutty complexity. Built to last, this is a fixture in many prestigious wine collections and will drink well for another decade at least.
column9: Lemon, Bread, Citrus Fruit, Grapefruit, Green Apple, Honey

column2: Tasmania is fast becoming one of the most exciting Australian Chardonnay regions. And for good reason. This is made there by Penny Jones, who worked for ten vintages at the famous Petaluma winery. Juicy. Fresh. Textured. Discover notes of stone fruit, pear juice and lemon curd, with a delicious minerality. Pair with ravioli dressed in butter.
column9: Hazelnut, Lemon, Nectarine, Peach, Vanilla

column1: Son of a Bull Riesling 2019, Tasmania
column2: Tasmania's island location means it's gaining serious acclaim for fresh and exciting wines that offer serious thirst-quenching enjoyment. Made from the cooler region of Piper Hills, and picked at optimum ripeness, this is your chance to see what all the fuss is about. A fresh and racy Riesling, Son of a Bull has notes of crunchy green apple, citrus and spice. Like its name suggests, it's best enjoyed young and would work wonders alongside vibrant and spicy Thai flavours.
column9: Wet Stones, Green Apple, Lemon, Lime

column2: You might think that Australia's too warm for the demanding Pinot Noir grape. But it has a long, luxurious ripening season on the cool-climate island of Tasmania. Taste the benefit in these notes of mulberry, cranberry, raspberry, dried herbs and toasty oak. This is at its best with duck breast.
column9: Red Fruit, Dried Herbs, Earth, Raspberry, Red Cherry

column2: Virginia Willcock’s interest in winemaking began in Perth, where as a teenager she assisted her father on a small vineyard. Her experience led her to the Margaret River, and today she is one of Australia’s most-awarded winemakers. Margaret River’s rich sunshine enriches the Chardonnay grapes with intense flavour. Cool nights chase sun-filled days that encourage a neat stroke of acidity that perfectly rounds each sip. Expect notes of lemon and tropical fruit, with a touch of ginger and a fresh hint of minerality on the finish. Its rounded texture and touch of acidity make it a fantastic match for seared scallops.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach, Smoke

column2: The Margaret River region, in Western Australia, makes some of the country’s finest Cabernet Sauvignon – and the founder of Vasse Felix is partly to thank. Inspired by European wines in the 1960s, Dr Thomas Brendan Cullity was the first to plant vines by the Wilyabrup Brook. Decades after his inaugural vintage, many other wineries have cropped up nearby, but Vasse Felix remains among the finest. This juicy Bordeaux-style blend has opulent strawberry and raspberry flavours and soft tannins. Pair with a steak sandwich or rich pork stew.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Leather, Spice, Sweet Spice

column1: Robert Oatley 'Signature Series' Chardonnay 2021/22, Margaret River
column2: Margaret River is widely respected for its European-style wines. This cooler-climate Australian region is perfect for Chardonnay grapes. Here, they mature slowly on the vine, making for complex and elegant Chardonnay that's celebrated worldwide. This is your chance to taste what the fuss is about at a lower price. It's rich and toasty, with notes of lemon, peach, vanilla, butter and cream that are best with salmon.
column9: Butter, Cream, Lemon, Peach, Vanilla

column1: Robert Oatley 'Signature Series' Cabernet Sauvignon 2018/19, Margaret River
column2: Bob Oatley’s mantra was that all wines should be a “darned good drink”. And his legacy continues today in the expert hands of Larry Cherubino. Larry's reputation has gained lofty heights in Australia's wine scene since establishing his own winery, Cherubino, in 2005. Some of his own Margeret River wines are priced upwards of £40 a bottle. This Signature Series Cabernet gives you the chance to enjoy his expertise for less. It's rich and vibrant, with flavours of blackcurrant, black plum and vanilla. The ripe tannins make for a long, elegant finish. Try it with BBQ beef ribs.
column9: Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Sweet Spice, Vanilla

column1: Cape Mentelle Cabernet Sauvignon 2017, Margaret River
column2: Cape Mentelle shot to fame with pioneering Cabernet Sauvignon in the 1970s. They're still rightfully considered a benchmark Margaret River winery. Take one sip of this famous Cabernet blend, and you'll see what all the fuss is about. Discover vibrant aromas of dark black fruits, cocoa and orange peel, and flavours of vanilla and bramble fruit. We suggest pairing it with steak and peppercorn sauce.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Cedar, Chocolate, Tobacco

column1: Cape Mentelle Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon 2019/21, Margaret River
column2: Cape Mentelle is one of the 'Founding Five' wineries of Margaret River, one of Australia's finest wine regions. Its Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon is fresh and juicy, with creamy flavours of lemon and fresh herbs and a textured complexity, thanks to four months of lees ageing.
column9: Lemon, Citrus Fruit, Gooseberry, Grass, Herbal

column2: Tahbilk is the oldest family-owned winery in Victoria, but they're still very much leaders of their region. They were named 2016 Winery of the Year by James Halliday, Australia's leading wine critic. The winery is now in the hands of the fifth-generation of the Purbrick family and holds carbon-neutral status. This Marsanne boasts mineral hints of grapefruit, citrus and Granny Smith apple. If you can wait, it'll gain a honeyed complexity over the next decade. Divine with smoked cheeses.
column9: Wet Stones, Citrus Fruit, Grapefruit, Green Apple, Herbal

column1: Ten Minutes by Tractor Estate Pinot Noir 2019/20, Mornington Peninsula
column2: This is a complex, silky red from one of Australia's finest Pinot Noir regions, Mornington Peninsula. This cool-climate region is a go-to for those in the know. And it really shows in Ten Minutes by Tractor's Estate Pinot Noir. Expect elegant notes of red fruit and a savoury complexity. Excellent with roast chicken.
column9: Smoke, Black Cherry, Black Fruit, Blackberry, Raspberry, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Savoury

column1: Rutherglen Shelley's Block Marsanne, Viognier, Rousanne 2018
column2: Rutherglen has long been known for its fortified whites. But if you scratch the surface, you'll find sublime dry whites too. This Marsanne, Viogner and Roussanne blend is reminiscent of top Châteauneuf-du-Pape Blanc. That's why it won a gold medal and a 95-point score at this year's International Wine Challenge. It's fermented in French oak and aged on character-building lees for seven months, resulting in a zesty palate of apricot, ginger and hazelnut.
column9: Tropical Fruit, Apricot, Butter, Honey, Melon, Peach

column2: Mornington Peninsula has long been Australia's best spot for top-shelf Pinot Noir - and it's tough to secure the best for less than £25. Not now! Taste the cool-climate excellence in structured notes of red fruits and spice and a luscious finish.
column9: Vanilla, Caramel, Coffee, Earth, Raspberry, Red Cherry, Smoke, Strawberry

column2: With access to some of Australia's oldest cool-climate vineyards, Stonier has scooped buckets of awards with its Reserve Chardonnay. This 2017 vintage won 97 Decanter points and 95 points at the International Wine Challenge. Made with just a dash of new-oak ageing, it's a fruity cocktail of melon, apple and grapefruit that's lined by sweet spices and a balancing flintiness.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach

column1: Ten Minutes by Tractor 'Down the Hill' Estate Pinot Noir 2017, Mornington Peninsula
column2: Mornington Peninsula is a sub-region of Victoria which, in recent years, has been identified as arguably the best area in Australia for cultivating the classic Burgundian varieties. The new 'Down the Hill' Estate Pinot Noir from Ten Minutes by Tractor is taken from warmer vineyards and matured for 11 months in French oak. The result is an approachable style, flush with red fruit and cranberry notes with dry tannins.
column9: Strawberry, Black Fruit, Blackberry, Raspberry, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Savoury, Smoke

column1: Ten Minutes By Tractor Estate Chardonnay 2019/20, Mornington Peninsula
column2: Mornington Peninsula is a sub-region of Victoria which, in recent years, has been identified as arguably the best area in Australia for cultivating the classic Burgundian varieties. From the estate's Main Ridge vineyard, this Chardonnay is whole-bunch pressed and fermented with wild yeasts in French oak barriques.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach, Smoke, Sweet Spice

column2: Petaluma believe that to make the best wine, you need to plant the right grape varieties in the right regions. This philosophy has certainly paid off – they’re renowned for their premium Yellow Label wines that showcase the best of Australia’s regional classics. It’s no surprise, then, that they chose Coonawarra to make this fantastic Cabernet. The famed terra rossa soils and cooling sea breezes create the ideal environment for the grapes, resulting in an elegant style similar to that of Bordeaux. Discover notes of cassis, mint, spice and eucalyptus, alongside soft tannins. Its complexity and depth of flavour will pair perfectly with red meats like beef or lamb.
column9: Blackcurrant, Earth, Spice, Redcurrant, Cassis

column2: Fifth-generation winemaker, Grant Burge,  is the name behind one of Australia's most respected and innovative producers. His family's roots in the Barossa Valley stretch back to 1855, when they immigrated from Wiltshire, England. Their classic South Australian wines are now recognised worldwide for their consistent quality as a result of being crafted from the finest Barossa fruit and passionate hands-on winemaking. This Shiraz – named in honour of the Burge family's winemaking heritage – is an excellent balance of classic Barossa power and elegant freshness. It's full of ripe plum, blueberry and strawberry with notes of black pepper, clove and chocolate. A wine this flavoursome will pair perfectly with punchy barbecued meats.
column9: Black Plum, Blackberry, Blueberry, Chocolate, Cloves

column2: Jam Shed was created with one thing in mind – to create delicious, seriously drinkable wines. They’ve travelled the world to find the best spots for their grapes and bring you flavourful bottles at exceptional value. This Shiraz comes from sun-soaked Aussie vineyards where the warm days really dial up the rich flavours. It’s soft and fruity with jammy notes of sweet dark cherry, plum, pepper and spice. It’s the perfect bottle to enjoy with your favourite pizza.
column9: Jammy, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Vanilla

column2: Jam Shed was created with one thing in mind – to create delicious, seriously drinkable wines. They’ve travelled the world to find the best spots for their grapes and bring you flavourful bottles at exceptional value. This Chardonnay comes from sun-soaked Aussie vineyards where the warm days really dial up the rich flavours. It’s rich and decadent with ripe notes of peach, citrus and a hint of toasty oak. Enjoy it with creamy pasta dishes.
column9: Butter, Peach, Vanilla

column2: Cape Mentelle is one of Margaret River’s 'founding five' wineries. A benchmark for quality, they're celebrated for having pioneered many of this Western Australian wine region's renowned styles. Despite other grape varieties often taking the limelight, Shiraz really flourishes here. A cooler coastal influence results in a more restrained style than the bold-and-jammy Shiraz of Barossa and Mclaren Vale. In a nod towards the traditional Syrah blends of the Rhône Valley's Côte-Rôtie, winemaker Eloise Jarvis blends her red Shiraz grapes with white Viognier to dial up the complexity. Viognier is rich and aromatic, so adding it to a blend brings freshness, softens tannins, and enhances any fruity and floral notes. Côte-Rôtie wines usually come with lofty prices, but this Cape Mentelle favourite means you can enjoy the style at a fraction of the cost. Expect a complex and structured wine with layers of violets, dark forest fruits and wild cherries. Intense savoury notes of tobacco, leather and spice mean this wine matches well with simple grilled meats or rich vegetable-laden stews.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Pepper, Blackcurrant, Liquorice, Smoke, Spice

column2: This release is part of Peter Lehmann's Masters range, and each wine is named after a person or event that has played a role in the Peter Lehmann story. This bottle is a tribute to 'Eight Songs for a Mad King' – one of Lehmann's favourite musical ensembles. The aim was to replicate the soft melodies in fine wine form. The result? An opulent, complex Shiraz that's been praised by numerous critics. The 2016 vintage was given a 93 point score by Australia's leading wine critic, James Halliday. Expect aromas of plum, cocoa and sweet spice. Partner with braised beef.

This release is part of Peter Lehmann's Masters range, and each wine is named after a person or event that has played a key role in the Lehmann story. Peter mentored countless people over his career, and this wine is a fitting tribute to his legacy – so you know you're in for something excellent. It’s smooth and velvety with lush blackcurrant, cedar and cocoa notes. Fantastic with braised lamb shanks.

Yalumba's Virgilius is often regarded as Australia's benchmark Viognier. And it's no wonder when you taste this intensely aromatic wine. Discover notes of apricot, ginger and cardamom. Enjoy with a creamy curry.
column9: Peach, Apricot, Floral, Honeysuckle

column1: Two Hands 'Angels' Share' Shiraz 2021/22, McLaren Vale
column2: Two Hands successfully prove that not all Aussie Shiraz is equal. Founded in the 1990s, their mission was to break the mould and showcase the diversity of this iconic grape. They’ve more than succeeded – and they’re now regarded as Shiraz experts. ‘Angels' Share’ was one of their very first wines. Its name refers to the small amount of wine that evaporates from oak barrels during maturation, which mediaeval winemakers believed angels took as they watched over their wines. It’s brilliantly bold and flavoursome – a full-on Australian Shiraz, with a silky texture and smooth tannins. Flavours of blueberry, dried herbs and a hint of game are ideal for barbecued meats.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Black Pepper, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Coffee, Jammy, Raisin, Red Fruit, Red Plum

column1: Two Hands 'Tenacity' Old Vine Shiraz 2021/22, Australia
column2: Two Hands founders Michael Twelftree and Richard Mintz had an ambition to make the best possible Shiraz-based wines from Australia's finest regions. They ensure this by only buying grapes from specialist growers. This way, they source the cream of the crop every harvest – and it’s paid off. Australia has some of the oldest vines in the world. Tenacity shows how the lower yields from old vines intensify all the flavours. If you like a full-throttle Australian Shiraz, you're in for a treat. This is full of ripe black-fruit flavours. Discover a juicy, velvety texture, with notes of chocolate and spice. Its intensity and richness mean it’ll complement hearty dishes like a beef stew.
column9: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Jammy, Spice

column1: Jim Barry 'The Lodge Hill' Shiraz 2020/21, Clare Valley
column2: Clare Valley has a relatively cool climate. It results in reds that are more elegant and fresh than those in many other Australian regions. And this Shiraz epitomises that style. It's made by the famous Jim Barry winery. So you can be sure of its excellence. Expect notes of blackcurrant, boysenberry, violets and a hint of fresh menthol. Delicious with meaty seared tuna.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Cloves, Sweet Spice, Tobacco

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£18.99 per bottle,75CL,Shiraz,,Screwcap,10.9,Smoke
column9: Coffee

column1: Jim Barry 'The Lodge Hill' Riesling 2021/22, Clare Valley
column2: Jim Barry purchased the land for The Lodge Hill vineyard in 1977 as he was sure it would produce some of the best Riesling in the Clare Valley. The plot sits high above sea-level. Grapes here are exposed to concentrated sunlight and cool nights which encourage gradual, slow ripening. The process helps retain the key characteristics of Riesling – fresh acidity and plenty of citrus. Come harvest time, gentle pressing preserves those natural flavours. The end result is mouthwatering. Dry, crisp and full of lemon, lime and grapefruit. Delicious alongside fresh seafood.
column9: Petrol, Citrus Fruit, Grapefruit, Green Apple, Honeysuckle, Lemon, Lime, Orange, Peach, Pear

column1: Petaluma ‘White Label’ Sauvignon Blanc 2021, Adelaide Hills
column2: Petaluma are renowned for crafting exceptional wines that represent the best of Australia’s regional classics. Their wines command premium prices – but if you want to taste their expertise for less, the ‘White Label’ range showcases their winemaking prowess without compromise on quality. For this crisp Sauvignon, they went to the cool slopes of Adelaide Hills. Vines here produce what’s widely considered to be the benchmark for Australian Sauvignon – grapes with refreshing acidity and intense fruity flavours. Expect zesty notes of grapefruit, melon and passionfruit with fresh-cut grass on the finish. It’s the perfect bottle to enjoy with light fish dishes
column9: Grapefruit, Grass, Lemon, Melon, Passionfruit

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2021 vintage.\",£10.99 per bottle,75CL,Viognier,,Screwcap,10.1,Stone Fruit
column9: Peach

column1: Penfolds 'Koonunga Hill Seventy Six' Shiraz-Cabernet Sauvignon 2019/21, South Australia
column2: When it comes to reds from Down Under, you can’t beat Penfolds. After all, this is the most famous premium winery in Australia – makers of the celebrated Grange. And this bold and spicy blend of Shiraz and Cabernet gives you a taste of the Penfolds wine mastery. It’s complex, structured and fruit-driven: think notes of plum, blackberry, blackcurrant and blueberry. Delicious chocolate and sweet spice notes add to its character and length. Crack it open an hour before sipping, and pair with a fine cut of beef.
column9: Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Sweet Spice, Vanilla

column2: Kalimna Bin 28 was first produced in 1959 and is Penfolds’ earliest Bin-collection wine. It’s named after Barossa Valley’s famous Kalimna vineyard, which was bought by Penfolds in 1945. The first releases were made entirely from this plot. Today, Bin 28 is made from multi-region vineyards, ensuring its ripe, robust character is balanced by freshness. It’s a showcase of warm-climate Australian Shiraz. So if you’re looking for just one ‘big Aussie red’ to add to your wine collection, make it this. It’s intense and full of ripe fleshy-fruit flavour. Aromas of plum, vanilla and baking spices lead to flavours of dark raspberry, chocolate and cola. Partner with seared steak.
column9: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Eucalyptus, Tobacco

column2: Penfolds is Australia's leading winery. The multi-region, multi-grape-varietal winemaking boom began here with Max Schubert. This wine is a tribute to him. It's made by Peter Gago, who has been recognised in The Queen’s Birthday Honours for his winemaking. And it does both these men proud. It’s a full-bodied, elegant wine, with notes of blueberry, mulberry, mocha and almond, smooth tannins, and a silky finish. Try it with beef.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Sweet Spice, Tobacco

column1: Jim Barry 'Cover Drive' Cabernet Sauvignon 2019/20, Australia
column2: Thought Australian wines were all sun, fruit and alcohol? Think again. The Jim Barry winery specifically chose to pick its Cabernet Sauvignon grapes from the cooler-climate Clare Valley and Coonawarra regions. In these spots, the grape develops deliciously over a long ripening period. The result is an Old World-esque wine with notes of blackberries, cherries, mocha and oak. 'This release hails from the Jim Barry winery - awarded the prestigious 'Winery of the year' accolade by the James Halliday Wine Companion Awards.'
column9: Tobacco, Black Cherry, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Cedar, Eucalyptus

column2: Yalumba has been in the same family since 1849. Over nearly two centuries, they’ve refined the art of show-stopping fine wine, as well as affordable everyday bottles known and loved worldwide. Tempranillo is often associated with Rioja. But Yalumba have broken conventions and put an exceptional Aussie twist on this traditionally Spanish grape. It has flavours of blackberries, cherries, chocolate and sweet spices. Try it with lamb cutlets.
column9: Spice, Black Plum, Blackberry, Dried Herbs, Liquorice, Red Cherry, Smoke, Sour Cherry

column1: Yalumba Y Series Sauvignon Blanc 2021/22, Australia
column2: The grapes behind Yalumba's Y Series Sauvignon Blanc are picked in the cool of night to bring every hint of grapefruit, Granny Smith apple and white blossom to your glass. It's also stirred on its complexity-building lees. So you're in for a structured sip.
column9: Tropical Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Gooseberry, Grapefruit, Grass, Lemon, Lime, Peach

column1: Two Hands 'Gnarly Dudes' Shiraz 2021/22, Barossa Valley
column2: 21 years ago, Michael Twelftree and Richard Mintz got chatting at a mutual friend’s engagement party. That night, Two Hands was born. Their idea was to make the best possible Shiraz-based wines from the most prized growing regions in Australia. They quickly won plaudits. This is the very best of modern-day Barossa Shiraz. Big, bold and chock-full of black-fruit flavour. It's even made by a man named Winemaker of the Year 2019 by the Barossa Barons, Richard Langford. Expect flavours of fig, blackcurrant, cedar, liquorice and tar. Try it with a rib-eye steak.
column9: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Cedar, Chocolate, Tobacco

column2: The key to Australian Shiraz is its intensity. It's known for two unmistakable features: plenty of dark-fruit flavour and a signature kick of pepper. We wanted to capture both of these features in abundance. When we tasted what we'd made from some of key spots in Barossa, there was just one thing to name it: Plum & Pepper. This is unashamedly big, bold and juicy, with a balancing acidity and a long finish. Try it with herby sausages.
column9: Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Jammy

column2: Torbreck 'The Laird' Shiraz costs £660 per bottle. On the same vineyard, made with the same care but from younger vines, its 'Woodcutter's' Shiraz is deliciously approachable in its youth - and you'll taste a delicious complexity that you'd expect in three-figure-sum reds in its turbocharged tapestry of black fruits, sweet spices and vanilla.
column9: Vanilla, Black Cherry, Blackberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Liquorice, Prune, Spice

column2: Shiraz is Australia's star grape. This is bold and full of dark bramble fruit - everything a big Aussie red should be. And there’s plenty of flavour for the price. Jammy blackberry and blackcurrant, pepper and vanilla spice. Excellent with beef short ribs.
column9: Vanilla, Black Pepper, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Jammy

column1: Two Hands 'Sexy Beast' Cabernet Sauvignon 2021/22, McLaren Vale
column2: Two Hands is already one of the finest Shiraz producers in Australia. Turning its hand to Cabernet Sauvignon, it's crafted a red that's chock full of blackcurrant, mocha, mint and a hint of graphite. Scoring a solid 90 Parker Points with this vintage alone, it's clear the winery is master of many.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Coffee, Smoke, Tobacco

column2: Penfolds played a pivotal role in the evolution of winemaking in Australia and across the world. A huge part of this was Max Schubert, Chief Winemaker for 27 years. He paved the way for those who continue to make Penfolds one of the world's greatest wineries. And this Chardonnay lives up to the great name. Expect fresh flavours of stone fruits, citrus, grapefruit, crème brûlée and nougat. Try this with creamy chicken.
column9: Vanilla, Hazelnut, Lemon, Nectarine

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£13.99 per bottle,75CL,Shiraz,,Screwcap,10.5,Black Pepper

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2018 vintage.\",£29.99 per bottle,75CL,Shiraz,,Screwcap,10.9,Liquorice

column1: Jim Barry 'McRae Wood' Shiraz 2013, Clare Valley
column2: The late Jim Barry is a godfather of Australian wines. His Clare Valley estate is now in the hands of his grandson, Tom, and was named Winery of the Year 2020 by Australia’s leading wine critic, James Halliday. This wine is made partially from grapes declassified from one of Jim Barry's finest vineyards, The Armagh, where bottles usually fetch £100+. As a result, this has been the choice of some of the most prestigious Michelin-starred restaurants since its first vintage. Expect balanced aromas of black berries and pepper and flavours of dark fruit and savoury spices. Its refined structure and long finish make it an excellent choice for intensely-flavoured lamb shanks, drizzled in jus.
column9: Blackberry, Earth, Red Fruit, Vanilla

column2: The Boxer Shiraz is perhaps the lightest and most accessible of Mollydooker's reds, although by any other standards it is still a hugely full-bodied and voluptuous wine. Made from the fruit of Mollydooker's own vineyards, aged in a mixture of new and old American oak, this wine offers a swathe of lush, velvety berry fruit, and layer upon layer of sweet spice, vanilla and dense, polished tannins.
column9: Vanilla, Black Cherry, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blueberry, Chocolate, Eucalyptus, Liquorice, Sweet Spice

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£34.99 per bottle,75CL,Chardonnay,,Screwcap,10.1,Vanilla
column9: White

column1: Shaw + Smith Sauvignon Blanc 2022/23, Adelaide Hills
column2: Shaw + Smith have made this Sauvignon Blanc for 30 years. Made from hand-picked grapes, aged on texture-imparting lees, this is no ordinary Sauvignon Blanc. Expect bright aromas of freshly-cut grass and pink grapefruit, with a luxuriously long finish. Serve with smoked salmon bagels. James Halliday, Australia's top wine critic, gave the 2019 vintage 95 points.
column9: Tropical Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Grapefruit, Green Apple, Lemon, Lime, Smoke

column2: Torbreck is one of the most celebrated producers in Barossa, the New World's full-bodied-Shiraz nirvana. Adding a dash of Eden Valley fruit to the mix, ageing the wine for 18 months in oak, it's created this heady assemblage of bluebearry, cream and spice with a long, velvet smooth finish. This vintage scored 94 Parker Points.
column9: Smoke, Black Cherry, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Chocolate, Earth, Eucalyptus, Liquorice, Mint

column1: Two Hands Ares Shiraz 2017/18, Barossa Valley
column2: Deep garnet-purple in color and intensely scented of blackberries and black plums with nuances of cedar, black pepper, Indian spices and loam, the medium to full-bodied Ares Shiraz has a solid core of youthful black fruit and exotic spice flavors with the oak standing out a little as do the firm, grainy tannins at this stage. It finishes with great length.
column9: Black Fruit, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Sweet Spice, Tobacco, Vanilla

column1: Two Hands 'Bella's Garden' Shiraz 2017/18, Barossa Valley
column2: Two Hands was started on a shoestring with two friends who had one task in mind: to create the best Aussie Shiraz going. It's now the only winery to be named in Wine Spectator's Top 100 nine times in a row. In the Australian hub of turbocharged Shiraz. Barossa, it's crafted this ripe, heady, dark cherry, vanilla cedar and briar-packed beauty that bagged 92 Parker Points
column9: Mint, Black Cherry, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blueberry, Earth, Leather, Liquorice

column1: Two Hands 'Lily's Garden' Shiraz 2018/19, McLaren Vale
column2: The Two Hands winery was formed by a duo of friends on a shoestring. It's now one of Australia's top fine-wine producers. The Lily's Garden is a heady bouquet of cherry, raspberry, mint, thyme and cream. Wine Advocate gave it 92 Parker Points.
column9: Vanilla, Black Cherry, Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Jammy, Sweet Spice

column1: Wolf Blass Yellow Label Chardonnay 2021/22, South Australia
column2: Yellow Label is the original series from Wolf Blass, one of Australia's most awarded wineries. Founded in the Barossa Valley, grapes are now carefully sourced from particularly ripe parcels of fruit across South Australia and matured in oak. A rich, honeyed, vanilla-flavoured Chardonnay, showing smooth, tropical fruit flavours on the creamy palate. Try it with Chinese-style fish dishes or more traditional roast chicken.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach

column2: Coonawarra is home to some of Australia's most famous vineyards – and world famous Cabernet Sauvignon. 'The Cigar' is no exception. It's named after the unique shape of Coonawarra's famous ‘terra rossa’ soils, and – quite rightly – is one of Yalumba's most popular fine wines. It's a rich and powerful red – expect bold notes of blackberry, strawberry, mocha and violets with soft, rounded tannins. Its velvety texture makes it a perfect partner for braised beef. The 2018 vintage was awarded gold at the 2022 Decanter World Wine Awards. Please be aware that this bottle may be closed with a cork or a screwcap, depending on the vintage.
column9: Tobacco, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Cigar Box, Eucalyptus, Mint

column2: \You may have tried Yalumba's entry-level work before. This is its Saturday-night wine. Almost equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Shiraz
column6: cherry and black pepper that boasts plenty of complexity. Wine Enthusiast gave it 93 points
column9: 75CL
column14: Vanilla, Black Cherry, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Cedar, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Smoke, Spice, Tobacco

column2: Barossa is where you’ll find some of Australia’s most sought-after wines. The region’s plentiful sunshine means the Shiraz here is big, bold and packed with intense black fruit flavour. Barossa was once famed for its metal-rich soils, but now it's flavourful red wines like Copper Kingdom that dominate the headlines. Copper Kingdom is a rich Shiraz with notes of black pepper and ripe dark fruits. Partner with a sizzling barbecued steak.
column9: Leather, Black Pepper, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Jammy

column1: Penfolds Bin 8 Shiraz-Cabernet Sauvignon 2019, South Australia
column2: Penfolds are widely considered to be Australia’s finest producer. Their iconic flagship wine, Grange, commands up to four-figure price tags – so you know you’re getting exceptional value with this. It’s made with grapes sourced from some of Southern Australia’s most renowned regions, including Barossa, McLaren Vale and Coonawarra. 12 months of oak ageing give it superb elegance and complexity, resulting in a wine that perfectly captured Penfolds’ celebrated house style. Expect rich flavours of ripe blackberry, dark cherry, cassis, cinnamon and clove. With its silky texture and plush tannins, it’ll make an excellent accompaniment to your Sunday roast beef.
column9: Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Strawberry, Vanilla, Cassis

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£10.99 per bottle,75CL,Grenache,Mataro

Deep and intense Primitivo – commonly referred to as Zinfandel – is typically found in California, Puglia and its native Croatia. But it grows excellently in Australia’s McLaren Vale, too, as this wine shows. A temperate Mediterranean-style climate and moderating sea influences result in a dark, richly perfumed red wine with aromas of strawberry jelly, roses, tea and orange. Flavours of spice and truffle – mixed with dark berry fruit – make this one to drink with barbecued ribs or lamb curry.
column9: Raspberry, Black Cherry, Black Plum, Blackberry, Jammy

column2: Penfolds’ Bin 2 was first released in 1960 – but was temporarily discontinued in the 1970s during the country’s white wine boom. Now it’s back, made under the watchful eye of Chief Winemaker Peter Gago. It’s a blend of Shiraz and Mataro – also known as Mourvèdre – and it’s a combination that’s still quite uncommon in Australian table wines. Soft and medium-bodied with subtle hints of oak, its rich redcurrant and plum flavours are delicious with roast venison. The 2019 vintage was awarded Silver at the 2022 Decanter World Wine Awards.
column9: Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Dried Herbs, Vanilla, Redcurrant

column1: Three Vintners Cabernet Sauvignon 2018, South Australia
column2: Three Vintners is a celebration of three generations of family winemakers, boasting the best of the secret that's been passed from grandfather to father to son. It's luscious, bold and chock-full of black fruits, mocha and sweet spice.
column9: Sweet Spice, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Raspberry

column2: Kangarilla Road is a Majestic classic. It's made by the acclaimed winemaker Kevin O'Brien, mainly from cool-climate Adelaide Hills vineyards. It's treated to a light use of oak, making it sleek and minerally-fresh. It truly showcases the best of modern Australian winemaking. It's elegant with notes of lemon sherbet, melon, pear and nectarine. Try it with a creamy chicken dish.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach

column2: In 1997, the O’Brien family purchased an old vineyard in the heart of McLaren Vale. They soon discovered that its ancient geology was perfect for nurturing complex and full-bodied Shiraz. The critics agree: Australia's leading wine critic, James Halliday, gave the winery the top Five Red Star rating. After just a sip of this wine, you'll see why. Packed with black fruits, dark chocolate and a creamy texture, it's a perfect pairing for beef short ribs.
column9: Vanilla, Black Cherry, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Chocolate, Raspberry, Tobacco

column2: Penfolds is unquestionably one of Australia's finest producers. Its most famous wine, Grange, today costs over £500. This is affectionately referred to as 'Baby Grange' by the winery, as it's   partly aged in barrels that the year before held its much-desired sibling. It's a blend of almost equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Shiraz that has flavours of liquorice, stewed plum, blackcurrant, dark chocolate and coffee. Drink now with slow-cooked lamb or age until 2040.
column9: Vanilla, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Black Pepper, Mint
Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach, Smoke

column2: Penfolds began in 1844 and is arguably Australia's finest winery. Today, chief winemaker is Newcastle-born Peter Gago. He makes St Henri with the same methods that have been applied since it began in the 1950s. It stands out amongst many of the other very best red wines in the country, as it doesn't rely on the use on new oak. It's concentrated and rich, with flavours of black cherry, blackberry, damson, chocolate, coffee, pepper and vanilla. Drink now with lamb or cellar until 2055.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Pepper, Blackberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Vanilla

column2: Taken from the cool Piccadilly Valley of the Adelaide Hills, Petaluma Chardonnay's creamy, turbocharged palate of cashews, butter and grapefruit won a huge 95 points and a Gold medal at the 2019 Decanter World Wine Awards. That's yet another trophy for the former 'Decanter Man of the Year' Brian Croser, who changed the wine world forever at Hardy's.
column9: Vanilla, Butter, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach, Smoke

column2: Clare Valley is one of Australia's oldest wine regions. To this day, it's most famed for its remarkable Riesling. And Petaluma is one of its best wineries. They carefully choose their vineyards to make the most of the region's amazing grape-growing conditions. The result is a Riesling that's bursting with beautiful citrus peel, orange blossom and tropical fruit notes. This is the perfect match for equally aromatic Thai food.
column9: Lime, Blossom, Citrus Fruit, Coconut, Cream, Floral, Grapefruit, Green Apple, Honey, Lemon

column1: Peter Lehmann Masters 'Margaret' Semillon 2013, Barossa Valley
column2: Peter Lehmann rewrote the rulebook on Barossa Semillon in the early 90s, eschewing oak and opting for an early-picked style that lent itself to ageing. The result is the Margaret Semillon. Containing only the best of the vintage, and released after five years of cellaring, it has aromas of citrus and some waxy, honeyed development that's typical of aged Semillon. On the palate you'll find notes of lemon, lanolin and beeswax.
column9: Peach, Butter, Floral, Grass, Honeysuckle, Lime, Passionfruit

column1: Peter Lehmann 'The Barossan' Shiraz 2019 Magnum, Barossa
column2: With rolling hills, hot, dry summers and some of the world's oldest vines, Barossa is arguably the finest spot in the New World for full-bodied, juicy reds. And this shows the very best of the region. Peter Lehmann Wines, one of the biggest names in Australian winemaking, went all over Barossa to capture its best elements. It's rich and heady with notes of raspberry, dark plum, strawberry, mocha and liquorice. What’s more, it's in celebration-perfect magnum form. Drink this with a steak.
column9: Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Leather, Smoke

column2: Peter Lehmann only make their coveted VSV range on the Barossa Valley's most exceptional vintages. When a 'Very Special Vineyard' delivers a great balance between the land and the fruit. This Shiraz shows notes of blackberry, dark chocolate and spice. Serve with braised beef.
column9: Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Vanilla

column2: Taking its name from Peter Lehmann's ex-Chief Winemaker, this Riesling is truly world-class. It has been named the best in the world six times and has won more than 80 trophies since its first vintage. Discover crisp notes of lime and flowers. Serve with oysters.
column9: Petrol, Green Apple, Lemon, Lime

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£33.99 per bottle,75CL,Shiraz,,Screwcap,10.9,White Pepper
column9: Liquorice

column1: St Hallett 'Old Block' Shiraz 2016, Barossa Valley
column2: Led by winemaker Helen McCarthy, St Hallett draws inspiration from the climatic diversity in the Barossa Valley. To qualify for their coveted Old Block wine, vines must be 40 years or older. Expect intense flavours of dark fruit. Divine with lamb ribs.
column9: Liquorice, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Earth

column2: Torbreck's Runrig Shiraz is blended with a dash of Viognier. So it's reminiscent of a structured, fragrant Côte Rôtie with some added Australian power. It has subtle tannins, lean acidity and a very long finish. Wine Spectator's Joe Czerwinski gave this 2012 vintage 97 points.
column9: White Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Blueberry, Chocolate, Coffee, Liquorice, Raspberry, Spice

column1: Two Hands 'Samantha's Garden' Shiraz 2018, Clare Valley
column2: Two Hands' 'Garden' range are examples of Shiraz wines that exmplify the particular area in which they are grown. This wine comes from a Clare Valley vineyard site, and the wine displays the typical eucalyptus notes and fineness of tannic structure that characterise Clare Valley Shiraz, enhanced by maturation for 18 months in second-fill French oak. Drink now - 2025.
column9: White Pepper, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blueberry, Liquorice, Smoke, Tobacco, Vanilla

column2: Made from the very best fruit nourished by 40-year-old vines on the estate's finest vineyards, aged in oak for two years and two in the bottle, the 'Visionary' is the top Cabernet Wakefield makes under £500. It's a structured bouquet of black fruits, olive, vanilla, cedar and mint that's framed by silky tannins and chased by a seemingly endless finish. Decanter gave it 95 points.
column9: Vanilla, Blackberry, Blackcurrant, Cedar, Eucalyptus, Forest Floor, Leather, Mint

column2: In 1961, Sir Robert Menzies said that Yalumba's Galway Vintage was the best Australian red he'd ever tasted. So they decided to make one even better and name it after this former Australian Prime Minister. They've done the name proud. This is structured and complex, with intense notes of red berries and a hint of oak influence. It's truly Coonawarra Cabernet at its best. Drink with tender beef short ribs.
column9: Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Vanilla
